Tattoos are attractive?

Author

Ashmita Biswas

Are tattoos attractive?

Tattoos or taboos? Analyzing the perception about tattoos.

About the Data

This data set is derived from the peasants of Srishti Manipal Institute to analyse the proportions of non-tattooed people who find tattoos attractiveâœ¨.

Data Dictionary

Qualitative Variables

Name: Name of the student

Gender: Gender of the student where; M = Male, F = Female

Tattoos_Attractive: Studentsâ€™ perception about tattoos being attractive or not

Hypothesis

  • Being in an art and design college, will the proportion of people finding tattoos attractive be more or be the same i.e. 1:1?

  • Does gender play a role in the way tattoos are perceived as?

Reading the Data

tattoo_data <- read_csv("~/Documents/R_work/Class work 2/ClassWork2/posts/A3/Datasets for A3/1-tattoo_attraction.csv") %>% 
janitor::clean_names(case = "snake")
Rows: 40 Columns: 3
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

Checking for missing data

tattoo_data %>%
  visdat::vis_miss()

Seems like there is no missing data! (Did i collect this data? Hmm)

Munging the data

tattoo_data_mod1 <- tattoo_data %>% 
mutate(gender = as.factor(gender),
tattoo_attractive = as.factor(tattoo_attractive))

Examining the Data

Taking a glimpse ðŸ‘€ of the Data

glimpse(tattoo_data_mod1)
Rows: 40
Columns: 3
$ name              <chr> "Aadya", "Abhinav", "Aditya", "Akash", "Amit", "Amogâ€¦
$ gender            <fct> F, M, M, M, M, M, M, M, M, F, M, F, M, F, M, F, F, Mâ€¦
$ tattoo_attractive <fct> Yes, Yes, No, Yes, No, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, No, Yes, â€¦

There are a total of 40 entries

Counting gender

tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
  dplyr::count(gender) %>%
  tt()
gender n
F 20
M 20

Observation

  • There is an equal number of male and female representation

Counting tattoo attractive perception

tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
  dplyr::count(tattoo_attractive) %>% 
  tt()
tattoo_attractive n
No 10
Yes 30 
tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
gf_bar(~tattoo_attractive, fill = "navy") %>% 
gf_labs(title = "Do students find tattoos attractive?",
       x = "Are tattoos attractive?",
       y = "Number of students")

Observation

  • We can see that exactly 75% of the students find tattoos attractive
  • This maybe due to the influence of the environment where tattoos are looked as a normal mark to have and/or younger generation embracing tattoos.

Does gender play a role in this?

tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
gf_bar(~tattoo_attractive, fill = ~gender, position = "dodge") %>% 
gf_labs(title = "Tattoo Attractiveness by Gender",
       x = "Are tattoos attractive?",
       y = "Number of students")
tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
gf_bar(~tattoo_attractive, fill = ~gender, position = "fill") %>% 
gf_labs(title = "Tattoo Attractiveness by Gender",
       x = "Are tattoos attractive?",
       y = "Number of students")
tattoo_data_mod1 %>% 
    count(across(c("gender", "tattoo_attractive"))) %>%
  tt()
gender tattoo_attractive n
F No 5
F Yes 15
M No 5
M Yes 15

Observation

  • There is an equal distribution amongst the 2 genders, which leads to the belief that there might be no gender bias in the perception of tattoos being attractive to the 2 genders.
vcd::structable(gender ~ tattoo_attractive, data = tattoo_data_mod1) %>%
  as.matrix() %>%
  addmargins() %>%
  as_tibble(rownames = "gender")
# A tibble: 3 Ã— 4
  gender     F     M   Sum
  <chr>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1 No         5     5    10
2 Yes       15    15    30
3 Sum       20    20    40
vcd::structable(gender ~ tattoo_attractive, data = tattoo_data_mod1) %>%
  vcd::mosaic(shade = TRUE, legend = TRUE,
              main = "Tattoo Attractiveness by Gender")
Warning in legend(residuals, gpfun, residuals_type): All residuals are zero.

Observation

  • The p value = 1 between Gender and Tattoo attractiveness.

  • This means there is no gender bias and the variables are independent / have no correlation to on another.

Inference
